subject: Data
title: Tim Berners-Lee and the Five-Star Open Data Model
description: A 60-second lesson on Tim Berners-Lee and the Five-Star Open Data Model.

hook.text: The inventor of the World Wide Web created a rating system for how 'open' your data really is.

buildup.text: Tim Berners-Lee's five-star model rates data from one star (available online) to five stars (linked open data).

discovery.text: One star: PDF file. Three stars: machine-readable format. Five stars: linked to other datasets with URIs.

twist.text: Most government open data sits at two or three stars â€” technically available but hard to combine with other datasets.

climax.text: The five-star model gave organizations a clear roadmap for improving data accessibility.

punchline.text: Open isn't binary. It's a spectrum from locked to linked.

quiz.question: What does five-star open data require?
options: Machine-readable data linked to other datasets with URIs
